awd_titl_txt: Self-Similar Theory of Electron Thermal Conduction in a Weakly Collisional Plasma
awd_abstract_narration:
The solar wind is a flow of hot particles, mostly electrons and ions, streaming from the Sun with the speed of millions of miles per hour.  As the solar wind expands, it is expected to cool.  However, at large distances from the Sun, the solar wind turns out to be not as cold as one would expect from the simple laws of thermodynamics. It is currently not well understood what heats the solar wind, since heating generally requires frequent collisions between the particles and the solar wind is nearly collisionless. A similar problem arises in other astrophysical and laboratory systems. This project will develop an efficient method for describing heating and heat conduction in collisionless plasmas.  It will utilize a special symmetry, self-similarity, often observed in expanding natural and laboratory plasmas. The outcomes of this research project will also be instrumental to improving the state of the art in space weather modeling, where accurate representations of the solar wind are important for correctly propagating the impacts of the solar activity on the Earth's magnetosphere.
    
The problem of electron heat conduction is central for understanding energy transport in natural and laboratory plasmas. Its general analytical solution is unknown, except for the Spitzer-Harm case when the electron mean free path is significantly shorter than the scale of a temperature gradient. Many natural plasmas, e.g., solar corona and solar wind, intracluster medium, are weakly collisional, where the above condition is not satisfied. A novel approach will be developed, which takes into account the fact that the physical parameters such as temperature, density, and magnetic field in such systems often decline as powers of the distance from the heat source. This allows one to find self-similar solutions of the full kinetic equation, and to construct the electron distribution function in a non-perturbative fashion.

por.por_cntn:
The solar corona consists of extremely hot ionized gas - plasma, with the temperature on the order of million degrees. The pressure of such plasma is tremendous. As a result, it cannot be contained by the solar gravity and expands from the solar corona with velocities from about 300 to 800 km/sec (about 1 million mph). Such hot ionized gas blowing from the sun forms the solar wind. It is composed mostly of electrons and protons.

It turns out that particles propagating away from the sun barely collide with each other. The nearly collisionless nature of the plasma fundamentally affects the structure, stability, and temperature of the expanding flow. For instance, it is crucial for our understanding of why the solar wind reaching Earth is much hotter than one would expect based on simple thermodynamic expansion models.

The electrons and protons behave differently in the solar wind. As the electrons are light, their velocities are much higher than that of the protons, so they escape the solar corona faster. As a result, the sun loses the negative charge faster and becomes positively charged to the potential of a few hundred volts. Eventually, the charge of the sun generates the so-called ambipolar electric potential in space that turns most of the electrons back to the sun. This potential helps the protons to catch up with the electrons, and  ensures that the net electric charge escaping the sun per unit time is zero.

A small fraction of extremely fast electrons overcome the trapping electric potential and escape the solar corona. Despite their small number, such electrons carry a significant fraction of energy, which may affect the dynamics and thermodynamics of the solar wind, for example, cause instabilities and heat the ambient plasma. Such an energetic stream of runaway electrons is termed a strahl. It is commonly observed in in situ measurements of the solar wind. 

The project studied the structure of the strahl, in particular, the velocity distribution function of the strahl electrons. Such a distribution is significantly affected by the magnetic field. The solar wind plasma is permeated by magnetic field lines spatially expanding from the solar corona. The magnetic force makes the electrons spiral along the magnetic field lines, as illustrated in the Figure.

As the magnetic-field strength decreases at larger heliospheric distances, the electron spiral trajectory becomes "stretched" in the radial direction, as shown, so that the particle velocities become progressively better focused along the magnetic field lines that guide the electron motion.

The electron motion is however not absolutely free. Occasionally, the electrons collide with plasma particles, which slightly defocuses the beam. These two processes - magnetic focusing and Coulomb collisions - form a rather non-trivial distribution of the strahl electrons. The shape of this distribution may critically affect the stability of the solar wind plasma as well as the energy transfer and heat conduction from the solar corona. In particular, it may explain why the solar wind does not cool down fast as it rapidly expands away from the sun, and remains relatively hot at large heliospheric distances.

One of the main outcomes of the project was the derivation of the electron strahl distribution function. Such a distribution has been obtained as a solution of the first-principle drift-kinetic equation supplemented by the Coulomb collision integral. The stability of the obtained electron distribution function was then investigated numerically. Several important results have been obtained. 

First, it was shown that the electron strahl formed by magnetic focusing and Coulomb scattering is stable to kinetic plasma modes, such as kinetic-Alfven waves and whistlers. This means that the obtained kinetic solution for the electron strahl is physically realizable, and may serve as a first-principle physical model for the solar-wind electron strahl.

Second, it was obtained that the full electron distribution function including the isotropic Maxwellian core and the strahl may, however, be unstable. This happens since for a strong enough strahl, the core of the electron function needs to be shifted in the velocity space in the direction opposite to the strahl, to maintain the zero net electron-proton drift. The velocity shift between the electron and ion cores leads to a (non-strahl resonating) instability that generates kinetic Alfven and whistler waves at scales comparable to the ion inertial scales. Our theory thus allows one to study kinetic scale plasma turbulence in the solar wind, the process responsible for the solar wind heating and solar wind temperature, which are fundamental and not fully solved problems in space physics.

Finally, we have studied analytically and numerically how the described processes operate at different distances from the sun. We have found that different instabilities become relevant at different heliospheric distances.  

The project supported two graduate students and led to publications and presentations at plasma physics and space physics conferences, seminars, and group meetings.
